bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 13, 1902

div1.p: Reed writes of his trip to Boston. He describes his hotel and the arrival of friends.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 13, 1902

opener.dateline:
HOTEL SOMERSET
COMMONWEALTH AVENUE
BOSTON
CHARLES A. GLEASON
2 P.M.
Boston, June 13 1902

div1.p:
Just a line
to say that after a hot trip to
N.Y. & a cool trip from there
to Boston, we arrived (Gen.
Bliss, Col. Black & myself) at
7.30 this morning- We found
that rooms had been pro-
vided for us here at the
Somerset -- very swell -- and
all at the expense of some
body else; which tickles me,
to say the least- Kean got
in, last night, and I wish that
you could see the swell suite
that we are now occupying.
It's just like rolling off a
log, & as I got a reduced rate
to Boston & return, I feel as
if I can stand the racket as
well as the average american
citizen- Beautiful rain here
this morning- I have spent
the morning, enjoying the Library
which was really quite a
treat. Gen. Wood has not
arrived yet, & we hear that
his yacht is delayed by the
fog- If he doesn't get here,
it will be like Hamlet
with that gentleman omitted.
Love to the Ping-Pongers --
expect to start home in the
morning- Love & kisses for sweet
miss Farmer-lady,
